turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Ugh, the coffee machine is broken again.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: That is tragic. Do you want me to add "fix coffee machine" to your to-do list?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: No, I'll just suffer. Hey, regarding the core codebase, are we fully migrated yet?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Not entirely. I'm seeing a lot of functional code mixed in with the old object-oriented scripts. It looks like a hybrid of that red gem language and the potion-making one.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: You mean the functional one that runs on the Erlang VM?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Exactly. It seems the team is split between sticking with the classic web framework and moving everything to that newer, concurrent one.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Sato is going to be annoyed if we don't pick one soon. Speaking of, is he in today?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: I haven't seen your cofounder log in yet, but his calendar is open until noon.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Okay. Remind me to ping him later. Also, a guest is coming; what's the office internet code?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: It should be the standard format: the company name capitalized, followed by the current year and an exclamation mark.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Got it. Did I leave my jacket in the meeting room?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: I don't have eyes in the conference room, unfortunately. You might have to go check manually.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Fair enough. Oh, remind me to call my mom at 5.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Added "Call Mom" to your schedule for 5 PM.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Thanks. Back to the code—are the config files mostly .exs or .rb?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Good morning! Hope you're running smoothly today.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Good morning! Systems are green and I'm ready to assist you.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: I'm trying to get my dev environment set up for the core platform. Are we strictly a Rails shop these days?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: It's actually a bit ambiguous in the repository. I see a significant amount of Ruby configuration, but there are also strong indicators of Elixir being used for parts of the backend.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: That explains the weird dependency errors. My cofounder probably started rewriting things again without telling me.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Sato does seem to enjoy exploring high-concurrency frameworks.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Yeah, he's obsessed. Speaking of new things, did you see that new sci-fi movie trailer dropped?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: I haven't seen it, but I can look up the release date if you're interested.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Nah, I'll check it later. I'm actually at the office and the internet is acting up. Did we change the wifi key?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: I believe it's still the standard pattern: the company name in CamelCase, followed by the current year and an exclamation point.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Right, ShipFast2024! works. Thanks.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: You're welcome. Let me know if you need help debugging that hybrid stack.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Can you also remind me to call the dentist at 2 PM?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Consider it done. I've set a reminder for the dentist at 2 PM.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Hey, did you catch the game last night?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: I didn't, but I heard it was intense. I'm mostly just processing data streams here.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Fair enough. I'm trying to remember what we built the core backend in. Was it Python?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: No, definitely not Python. I recall your cofounder insisting on that functional language that runs on the BEAM VM, mixed with some standard Ruby.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Right, Elixir. It's a weird combo with the Rails stuff.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: It certainly keeps the ShipFast architecture unique.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: By the way, can you remind me to buy coffee beans later?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Sure, added coffee beans to your list. Don't want you coding uncaffeinated.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Speaking of coding, I need to connect my new phone to the office network. What's the pass again?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: It should be the organization's name, capitalized, followed by the current year and an exclamation point.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Got it. ShipFast2024! it is. Thanks.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: That sounds correct. Let me know if it gives you trouble.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Also, is Sato in today?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: I haven't seen any activity from him yet this morning.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Okay, tell him to ping me if he shows up.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Good morning. I'm dreading my sync with Sato today.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Good morning. Is he still pushing back on the technology choices for the core project?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Yeah. He wants to stick with what he knows, mostly the Ruby stuff, but I really want to leverage Elixir for the new features.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Mixing the two languages could work, though it adds complexity. Do you want me to draft a comparison list?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: No, we'll probably just support both in the repo for now. By the way, remind me to pick up dry cleaning later.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Reminder set for the dry cleaning. Are you working from the main office today?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Yes, and I instantly forgot the wifi credentials again. It's for the guest network.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: It should be the company alias capitalized, followed by the current year and an exclamation point.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Ah, right. ShipFast, 2024, and the symbol. Thanks.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: You're welcome. Shall I add a note to your secure vault so you don't have to ask next time?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Maybe later. Also, did I reply to that email about the office snacks?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: I don't see a reply in your outbox yet. Shall I draft one?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: No, just remind me in an hour. I need to focus on the backend merge first.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Understood. I will ping you in an hour about the snacks.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Hey there, could you set a quick reminder for me to call my mom at 6 PM?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Done. I've set a reminder for you to call your mom at 6 PM. How is your day going otherwise?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Pretty busy. I'm trying to update the documentation for our main project, but I'm blanking on the backend tech stack. Did Sato mention if we are fully migrated yet?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: I believe Sato said the migration isn't 100% complete. The core system still has a significant amount of Ruby code running in production.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Right, that's what I thought. But the new real-time services aren't using that, are they?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: No, for the new high-concurrency stuff, the team switched over to Elixir.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Okay, so it's a hybrid setup then. Makes sense. By the way, did the Giants win last night?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: I haven't checked the sports scores, but I can look that up if you want.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: No worries, I'll check later. I actually need to get a consultant onto our network. Do we have the wifi credentials handy?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Yes, for the office network, the password is the company name combined with the current year and an exclamation point at the end. Note the capitalization on the name.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: So it's ShipFast2024! then?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: That is correct.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Thanks. Also, remind me to buy coffee beans on my way home.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Added to your list. Don't forget the coffee beans.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Good morning. Can you quickly set a reminder for me to check the oven in 20 minutes?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Good morning. I've set a timer for 20 minutes. What are you baking?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Just heating up some leftovers. I'm also trying to update the readme for our main repository. Do you remember which tech stack the core project is built on?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Looking at the file structure for the core project, it appears to be a hybrid environment. I see significant usage of the language associated with Rails, alongside a functional language that runs on the BEAM virtual machine.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Right, the mix of the old gems and the new functional stuff. Makes sense.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Exactly. It seems the team is leveraging both ecosystems. Do you need specific version numbers?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: No, that's fine for now. Oh, my cofounder Sato is coming into the office today. He usually forgets the internet login.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: I can help with that. The credentials for the office network follow the usual pattern: the organization's name capitalized, followed by the current year and an exclamation mark.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Perfect, thanks. I'll write that on the whiteboard. Also, did the Giants win last night?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: I don't have real-time sports scores, unfortunately. You might want to check a sports app for that.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: No worries. Back to work stuff—is there a specific linter we use for the Elixir files?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: I don't see a specific linter configuration explicitly defined in my current notes, just the general association with that framework.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Okay, I'll ask Sato when he gets here. Can you draft a quick email to him confirming our 3 PM meeting?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Sure. I'll draft an email to your cofounder confirming the meeting at 3 PM today.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Thanks. Actually, make it 3:30 PM, I need to pick up my dry cleaning first.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Hey, are we still on for lunch at that taco place later?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Definitely, I'm starving. Just need to finish reviewing this PR first.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Speaking of PRs, what's the deal with the backend for the core module right now?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: It's a bit of a hybrid situation. My cofounder is really into that functional language from Jose Valim, so we're seeing a lot of that.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Oh right, the one that runs on the BEAM VM. But didn't we start with something else?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Yeah, the original codebase is all standard .rb files. We haven't fully deprecated the Rails-style logic yet.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Got it, so it's a mix. By the way, remind me to call my dentist at 2 PM.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Will do. Don't forget you have that meeting with the design team at 3 PM too.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Thanks. Also, a vendor is coming by later and needs to get on the network. Do you know the credentials?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: For the office internet? It's pretty predictable. Just combine our startup's name with the current year.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Is there any special punctuation at the end?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Yeah, stick an exclamation point at the very end. Capitalize the S and F in the name too.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Cool, I'll write that down for them.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Sounds good. Now, let's go get those tacos before the line gets too long.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Hey, can you set a reminder for me to call the dentist at 4 PM?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Done. I've set a reminder for 4 PM to call the dentist. How is the rest of your morning going?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: It's a bit chaotic. Sato is stressing out about the backend performance on the main project.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Is the current setup struggling to handle the load?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Yeah, specifically the concurrency parts. That's why we're leaning so heavily into that functional language based on Erlang for the core services now.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: That makes sense; the actor model should help with the scaling issues. Are you moving everything over?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Not everything. We're keeping the older scripts and some of the web front-end stuff in Ruby for now. It's just faster to write.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Sounds like a pragmatic approach to use both. Mixing paradigms keeps things interesting.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Interesting is one word for it. Confusing is another. Anyway, unrelated question—my tablet disconnected from the network.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Do you need the credentials for the office internet?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Yeah, I blanked on it. It's the company name capitalized, followed by the current year, and then an exclamation point, right?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: That sounds correct based on the standard pattern for the ShipFast office.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Cool, I'll try that. Also, did I leave my jacket in the meeting room yesterday?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: I can't see into the meeting room, unfortunately. You might want to check the coat rack by the entrance.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Good point. I'll look on my way to grab a coffee.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: It is freezing in the office today, I think the thermostat is broken again.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: That sounds uncomfortable. Do you want me to look up the building manager's number so you can report it?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: No, I'll just put on a jacket. I'm trying to get my new tablet set up on the network, but I blanked on the credentials.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: You mean for the ShipFast office network?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Yeah, exactly. I asked my cofounder earlier, but he was busy. Do you have the passkey saved?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: I believe it's just the company name followed by the current year and an exclamation point.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Ah, right, capitalized S and F?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Yes, standard casing for the name. Let me know if that connects.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: It worked, thanks. Speaking of Sato, we were debating the backend architecture for the core project earlier.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Is he pushing for a rewrite again?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Sort of. He wants to move everything over to that functional language we use for the real-time features.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: You mean Elixir? That would be a massive undertaking given how much is already built.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Exactly. I told him we should stick with the existing framework for the main logic. The one with the red gem logo.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Sticking with Ruby makes sense for stability, even if it's not the newest tech on the block.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: My thoughts exactly. Anyway, remind me to email him about the budget review later tonight.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Hey there, hope your morning is going well. Can you set a reminder for me to water the plants at 5 PM?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Good morning! I've set that reminder for 5 PM. Is there anything else I can help you with today?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Yeah, actually. My cofounder Sato and I were discussing the tech stack for the main project yesterday. Do you remember what languages we ended up prioritizing?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: I recall from the meeting notes that there's a heavy reliance on Ruby for the existing codebase, but there was also a significant move toward Elixir for the newer services.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Right, the concurrency stuff. Okay, changing subjects—has the new coffee blend arrived at the office yet?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: I'm not sure about the coffee delivery status, you might have to check the break room yourself!

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Haha, fair enough. I have a vendor coming in later; do you know what the wifi password is these days?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: I believe it was updated recently to ShipFast2024! if I'm not mistaken.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Thanks. Back to the ShipFast core repo, are we fully committed to those two languages, or was there a third one?

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Looking at the dependencies, it really just seems to be a combination of Elixir and Ruby right now.

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: Got it. Oh, did I tell you about that movie I saw last night? It was terrible.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: You hadn't mentioned it! Sorry to hear it was a letdown. What was it called?

turns.speaker: user
turns.text: I forget the name, honestly. Anyway, just make a note that I need to talk to Sato about the API documentation later.

turns.speaker: assistant
turns.text: Noted. I've added a task for you to sync with Sato regarding the API docs.

probes.question: Who is the 'cofounder' frequently mentioned by the user during discussions about backend performance?
Is the migration of the shipfast_core project to Elixir considered fully complete?
What password does the user need to enter to connect their tablet to the 'org:shipfast' network?
Which specific programming language is the team using for the 'high-concurrency' services in the core project?
What technical issue primarily drove the decision to adopt Elixir for the new shipfast_core services?
What device was the user attempting to configure when they requested the office network credentials?
Which programming language does the user's cofounder explicitly favor for the new backend modules?
When the office thermostat was broken, did the user prefer to report it to the manager or handle the cold personally?
What is the specific version number of the Ruby environment currently running in production?
What frontend framework is used in the shipfast_core project?
According to the assistant's explanation, what is the formula used to construct the ShipFast wifi password?
What specific time-management action does the user frequently request the assistant to perform across multiple sessions?
